case_name: Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos.475-478 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos.475-478 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeals from order dated July 14, 1961 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition Nos. 516 to 519 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the order dated July 14, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition Nos. 516 to 519 of 1960.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: four appeals arise from four, writ petitions filed by the appellant, the Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation,

facts.text: Writ petitions filed against Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh against the Income-tax Officer, and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, respondents 1 and 2 respectively,

facts.text: Claimed writ of prohibition restraining respondents from collecting tax or taking proceedings under Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: in which it claimed a writ of prohibition restraining them from companylecting any tax, or taking any proceedings under the Indian Income Tax Act against them.

facts.text: Claimed quashing of assessment orders passed on 29th February, 1960 for years 1958-59 and 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: In its writ petitions, the appellant further claimed an order, writ, or other appropriate direction quashing the assessment orders passed by respondent No. 1 on the 29th February, 1960. for the years 1958-59 and 1959-60.

facts.text: Tax imposed for 1958-59: Rs. 13,60,963.86 nP. for period 11-1-1958 to 31-3-1958.

anchor.surface_text: For the first year, a tax of Rs. 13,60.963.86 nP. has been imposed for the period 11-1-1958 to the 31-3-1958,

facts.text: Tax levied for 1959-60: Rs. 34,44,430.48 nP. for period 1-4-1958 to 31-3-1959.

anchor.surface_text: and for the latter year, a tax of Rs. 34,44,430.48 nP. has been levied for the period 1-4-1958 to 31-3-1959.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petitions with costs.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the parties, the High Court has dismissed the appellants writ petitions with companyts.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from High Court for appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court and it is with the said certificate that these four appeals have been brought to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant Corporation established under Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950 by notification of Andhra Pradesh Government.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant was established under the Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950  No. 64 of 1950   hereinafter called the Act  by a numberification issued by the Andhra Pradesh Government

facts.text: Corporation functioning with effect from 11th January, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and it has been functioning with effect from the 11th January, 1958.

facts.text: Before formation of Corporation, road transport was a department of Government of Hyderabad and after integration, run by Government of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Before the formation of the appellant Corporation, the road transport was a depart- ment of the Government of Hyderabad and after integration of Hyderabad with Andhra Pradesh, it was run by the Government of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: During previous period, road transport treated as exempt from income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: During the whole of this period, the road transport was treated as exempt from income-tax.

facts.text: Notice under s. 22 of Income-Tax Act served on appellant on 29th January, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: and so, a numberice under s. 22 of the Income-Tax Act was served on the appellant on the 29th January, 1959.

facts.text: Impugned assessment orders passed in pursuance of proceedings after service of notice.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the proceedings which were taken after service of the numberice, the impugned orders of assessment were passed.

facts.text: Appellant urged before ITO that it does not fall under any of five categories of assessees under s. 3 of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Income-tax Officer, it was urged by the appellant that since the appellant was an independent body carrying on the business of road transport, it did number fall Linder any of the five categories of assessees under s. 3 of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: Appellant argued net income goes to State of Andhra Pradesh under s. 30 of the Act, immune under Art. 289.

anchor.surface_text: it was neither an individual, number a Hindu undivided family, number a firm, number a companypany, number an association of persons, and as it was outside the said five categories of assessees, numbertax companyld be levied against it. It was further argued that the net income of the appellant ultimately goes to the State of Andhra Pradesh under s. 30 of the Act,

facts.text: Appellant contended it was a local authority exempt from income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: Yet, another companytention was raised in support of the plea that the numberce issued by respondent No. 1 was invalid, and that was that the appellant was a local authority exempt from income-tax.

facts.text: All contentions rejected by ITO, leading to assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: All these companytentions were rejected by respondent No. 1, with the result that the impugned orders of assessment came to be passed.

facts.text: High Court held appellant is not a State-owned Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that the appellant is number a State- owned Corporation and that it is number carrying on business on behalf of the Government.

facts.text: High Court held trade or business not incidental to ordinary functions of government, no declaration under Art. 289(3).

anchor.surface_text: It has also observed that the trade or business which the appellant was carrying on was number incidental to the ordinary functions of government, and since numberdeclaration had been made to that effect under Art. 289 3 , the appellant companyld number rely on Art. 289 1 .

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that appellant is local authority.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the appellant was a local authority which was urged before the High Court was rejected,

facts.text: High Court held no repugnancy between Income-tax Act charging section and sections 28,29,30 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and the argument that the charging section of the Income-tax Act was repugnant with the material provisions of the Act, such as sections 28, 29 and 30, was also held to be without any substance by the High Court.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C.J. on March 5, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 289 1  of the Constitution, and that raises the question about the companystruction and effect of the provisions of the three clauses of Art. 289. Let us, therefore, read the said article 289.  1  The property and income of a State shall be exempt from Union taxation. Nothing in clause  1  shall prevent the Union from imposing, or authorising the imposition of, any tax to such extent, if any, as Parliament may by law provide in respect of a trade or business of any kind carried on by, or on behalf of, the Government of a State, or any operations companynected therewith, or any property used or occupied or any income accruing or arising in companynection therewith. Nothing in clause  2  shall apply to any trade or business, or to any class of trade or business, which Parliament may by law declare to be incidental to the ordinary functions of government.

concepts.interpretation: Cl.1 exempts State's income; cl.2 exception for trade/business by/on behalf of State; cl.3 exception to cl.2 for incidental functions.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 3 of the Income-tax Act it was neither an individual, nor a Hindu undivided family, nor a firm, nor a company, nor an association of persons, and as it was outside the said five categories of assessees, no tax could be levied against it.

Let us, therefore, read the said article 289.  1  The property and income of a State shall be exempt from Union taxation. Nothing in clause  1  shall prevent the Union from imposing, or authorising the imposition of, any tax to such extent, if any, as Parliament may by law provide in respect of a trade or business of any kind carried on by, or on behalf of, the Government of a State, or any operations connected therewith, or any property used or occupied or any income accruing or arising in connection therewith.

issues.text: whether the income derived by the appellant from its trading activity is the income of the State under Art. 289(1)

anchor.surface_text: The main point which we are examining at this stage is is the income derived by the appellant from its trading activity, income of the State under Art. 289 1 ? In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in the negative. Far from making any provision which would make the income of the Corporation the income of the State, all the relevant provisions emphatically bring out the separate personality of the corporation

arguments.claim: Scheme of Art.289: cl.1 exempts State's income; cl.2 exception for trade on behalf of State; cl.3 exception to cl.2.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of Art. 289 appears to be that ordinarily, the income derived by a State both from governmental and number- governmental or companymercial activities shall be immune from income-tax levied by the Union, provided, companyrse, the in- companye in question can be said to be the income of the State.

arguments.claim: American doctrine of immunity of instrumentalities rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The said doctrine has been categorically rejected by this Court in State of West Bengal v. Union of India ... has been decisively rejected by the Privy Council as inapplicable

arguments.claim: No repugnancy between IT Act and RTC Act ss.28,29,30; latter does not contemplate exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, there is really numberrepugnancy at all. Basing himself on the provisions of sections 29 and 30, the Advocate-General companytends that these two provisions show that the Act did number companytemplate the payment of income-tax.

holdings.text: The income derived by the appellant from its trading activity is not the income of the State under Art. 289(1).

anchor.surface_text: The main point which we are examining at this stage is is the income derived by the appellant from its trading activity, income of the State under Art. 289 1 ? In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in the negative. Far from making any provision which would make the income of the Corporation the income of the State,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Road Transport Corporations Act provisions emphasize separate corporate personality; income vests in corporation, not State; ss.28-30,38,39 confirm this.

holdings.text: A corporation established under the Road Transport Corporations Act has a separate legal entity distinct from the State.

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine that a corporation has a separate legal entity of its own is so firmly rooted in our traditions derived from common law that it is hardly necessary to deal with it elaborately and so, prima facie, the income derived by the appellant from its trading activity cannot be claimed by the State

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of separate legal entity rooted in common law; RTC Act ss.3-5,23-30,38,39 treat corporation as distinct body corporate with own property, funds, liabilities.

holdings.text: Clause 2 of Art. 289 carves out an exception from the exemption in cl.1 for trade or business carried on by or on behalf of the Government of a State; cl.3 is exception to cl.2.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of Art. 289 appears to be that ordinarily, the income derived by a State both from governmental and non- governmental or commercial activities shall be immune from income-tax levied by the Union, provided, of course, the in- come in question can be said to be the income of the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of cls.1,2,3: cl.1 general exemption for State's income/property; cl.2 authorizes tax on trade by/on behalf of State; cl.3 restores exemption if declared incidental.

holdings.text: Even if trading activity covered by Art.289(2), exemption under cl.1 requires it to be income of the State.

anchor.surface_text: If the trading activity carried on by the appellant is sought to be brought into Art. 289(1) solely as a result of the construction of Art. 289(2), the test... is whether or not the requirement of Art. 289(1) is satisfied and that requirement clearly is that the income... must be the income... of a State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemption under cl.1 limited to State's own income/property; cl.2 exception assumes inclusion in cl.1 but authorizes taxation unless incidental per cl.3.

holdings.text: The appellant is not a local authority exempt from income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: He frankly told us that he did not propose to challenge the correctness of the conclusion recorded by the High Court that the appellant is not a local authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court conclusion not challenged by appellant; accepted by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: There is no repugnancy between the charging section of the Income-tax Act and sections 28, 29, 30 of the Road Transport Corporations Act.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, there is really no repugnancy at all. Basing himself on the provisions of sections 29 and 30, the Advocate-General contends that these two provisions show that the Act did not contemplate the payment of income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: RTC Act ss.28-30 deal with fund administration and profit disposal, not tax exemption; no need for specific tax provision; Finance Acts annually impose tax; ss.43 in other Acts confirmatory only.

holdings.text: The American doctrine of immunity of State instrumentalities from federal taxation is inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: The said doctrine has been categorically rejected by this Court in State of West Bengal v. Union of India ... has been decisively rejected by the Privy Council as inapplicable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected in State of WB v. UOI; decision based on Art.289 construction, not doctrine; Privy Council precedents confirm inapplicability to federal structures like India.

precedents.citation: Akadasi Padhan State of Orissa Others 1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 691

anchor.surface_text: Akadasi Padhan State of Orissa Others 1  In that case, this Court had occasion to consider the scope and effect of the provisions contained in Art. 19 6

precedents.case_name: Akadasi Padhan v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Scope of Article 19(6) allowing the State to carry on trade or business through agents appointed by it
precedents.cited_holding: though normally, the trade specified in the clause would be carried on by the State departmentally or with the assistance of public servants appointed in that behalf, there may be cases of some trades or business in which it would be open to the State to employ the services of agents, provided the agents work on behalf of the State and not for themselves

precedents.citation: Mark Graves. John J. Merrill and John P. Hennessy v. People of the State of New York Upon the Relation of James B. Okeefe 83 Law. Ed. 927

anchor.surface_text: Mark Graves. John J. Merrill and John P. Hennessy v. People of the State of New York Upon the Relation of James B. Okeefe 1 . In that case Stone J. who spoke for the Supreme Court of America. has observed that when the national government lawfully acts through a corporation which it owns and controls, those activities are governmental functions entitled to whatever tax immunity attaches to those functions when carried on by the government itself through its departments.

precedents.case_name: Graves v. New York ex rel. O'Keefe
precedents.cited_proposition: Activities of government-owned and controlled corporation are governmental functions entitled to tax immunity
precedents.cited_holding: when the national government lawfully acts through a corporation which it owns and controls, those activities are governmental functions entitled to whatever tax immunity attaches to those functions when carried on by the government itself through its departments

precedents.citation: Clallan County v. United States of America 68 Law. Ed. 328

anchor.surface_text: Clallan County v. United States of America,  2  it was held by the Supreme Court of America that a State cannot tax the property of a corporation organised by the Federal government to produce material for war purposes, the property of which is conveyed to it by, or bought with the money of, the United States, and used solely for the purposes of its creation.

precedents.cited_proposition: State cannot tax property of federal corporation used solely for federal purposes
precedents.cited_holding: not only the agent was created, but all the agents property was acquired and used for the sole purpose of producing a weapon for the war. This is not like the case of a corporation, added the learned Judge, having its own purposes as well as those of the United States, and interested in profit on its own account

precedents.citation: State of West Bengal v. Union of India 1964 3 S.C.R. 787

anchor.surface_text: The said doctrine has been categorically rejected by this Court in State of West Bengal v. Union of India 1  Speaking for the majority of the Court, Sinha C. J. observed that it was futile to attempt the resuscitation of the long exploded doctrine of the immunity of instrumentalities

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Rejection of the American doctrine of immunity of state instrumentalities from federal taxation
precedents.cited_holding: it was futile to attempt the resuscitation of the long exploded doctrine of the immunity of instrumentalities which originating from the observations of Marshall, C. J., in M Culloch v. Maryland, has been decisively rejected by the Privy Council

anchor.surface_text: originating from the observations of Marshall, C. J., in M Culloch v. Maryland, 2  has been decisively rejected by the Privy Council as inapplicable to the interpretation of the respective powers of the States and the Centre under the Canadian and Australian Constitutions

anchor.surface_text: In Special Reference No. 1 of 1962. In re. Sea Customs Act  1878 , Section  1 1964 1 S.C.R. 371. 407.  3   1887  12 A.C. 575.  2   1819  4 Wheat, 316 at p. 436.  4  1907 A.C. 81 20 2 , 1  a Special Bench of this Court by a majority as e that the immunity granted to the States in respect of Union taxation, under Art. 289 1  does not extend to duties of customs including export duties or duties of excise.

precedents.cited_proposition: Article 289(1) immunity does not extend to duties of customs or excise
precedents.cited_holding: the immunity granted to the States in respect of Union taxation, under Art. 289 1  does not extend to duties of customs including export duties or duties of excise

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we may usefully refer to the observa- tions made by Lord Denning in Tamlin v. Hansaford  1 . In the eye of the law, said Lord Denning, the corporation is its own master and is answerable as fully as any other person or corporation.

precedents.cited_proposition: Corporation has separate legal personality distinct from the State or Crown
precedents.cited_holding: In the eye of the law, the corporation is its own master and is answerable as fully as any other person or corporation. It is not the Crown and has none of the immunities or privileges of the Crown

anchor.surface_text: The main point which we are examining at this stage is is the income derived by the appellant from its trading activity, income of the State under Art. 289 1 ? In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in the negative. Far from making any provision which would make the income of the Corporation the income of the State,
The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

The doctrine that a corporation has a separate legal entity of its own is so firmly rooted in our traditions derived from common law that it is hardly necessary to deal with it elaborately and so, prima facie, the income derived by the appellant from its trading activity cannot be claimed by the State
The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

The scheme of Art. 289 appears to be that ordinarily, the income derived by a State both from governmental and non- governmental or commercial activities shall be immune from income-tax levied by the Union, provided, of course, the in- come in question can be said to be the income of the State.
The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

If the trading activity carried on by the appellant is sought to be brought into Art. 289(1) solely as a result of the construction of Art. 289(2), the test... is whether or not the requirement of Art. 289(1) is satisfied and that requirement clearly is that the income... must be the income... of a State.
The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.
